column9: First, if you have obstructive sleep apnea, go directly to cpap machine and bypass provigil. Yes it works. Prior to starting my cpap usage I had a hard time doing a four hour drive. Sleep apnea does more than put stress on you due to lack of sleep. It is a outright health hazard in its own right. Deal with it right.So, why do I take this drug from time to time? Frankly its a "go" drug and used for that purpose by the military. Right now, I am in a personal situation that will require that I be awake and functional for about 48 hours straight. The Provigil will do that for me. I do not recommend that you go over the 48 hour limit much. At 72 hours a lot of people start to hallucinate. Your brain does need sleep sooner or later. It evolved like that and its not nice to trick mother nature too much. But for emergency shift work, time zone hopping, and all the rest of those sort of short term usages off label from narcoleptic things, this is an amazingly effective drug. Your mileage may vary a bit. The effectiveness of Provigil is somewhat dependent on your own brain chemistry. Be careful with the usage. You can fall into the pill to wake up and then the pill to go to sleep habit. That is not anything smart to do.

column9: PROVIGIL KILLS. Read this again: PROVIGIL KILLS. Are you aware that the FDA has already SPECIFICALLY DECLINED TO APPROVE the use of Provigil for the treatment of ADHD. This happened just 2 years ago, but you will not read about it because Provigil was tested under a FAKE name: Sparlon. Look it up on FDA.org. For over a decade, Provigil's manufacturer, Cephalon, has been promoting this drug as a safer alternative to Dexedrine or Adderall for ADHD. One of their sales reps talked my doctor into switching me from Dexedrine to Provigil because it was safer. At the time (2 years ago) I had taken Dexedrine for 12 years with no side effects. Within a week after I reached the 'target' dosage I went into psychotic delusions, my blood pressure went down to 75/40, I went into cardiogenic shock, acute kidney failure, acute heart failure and suffered significant brain damage. I spent 20 days in the ICU and my doctors estimated that, simply for not dying within 24 hours, I had overcome odds of 200 to 1. In part because of my case the FDA ordered that Provigil labels include warnings about hypersensitivity to Provigil that people have been dying from without notice since Provigil was released 10 years ago because the physicians who performed autopsies either never learned that their 'patient' had recently started taking Provigil or if they knew they did not suspect Provigil as the cause of death.
